intro: Pecteilis ophiocephala, commonly known as the ghost flower, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its delicate, fern-like foliage. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers that bloom in late summer. Its unique appearance and habitat preferences make it an interesting subject for botanical study. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in wetlands and along stream banks.
